an3.70:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
an3.70:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

an3.70:1.3.pli: Atha kho visākhā migāramātā tadahuposathe yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho visākhaṃ migāramātaraṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an3.70:1.3.eng: Then Visākhā, Migāra’s mother, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to her,

an3.70:1.4.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, visākhe, āgacchasi divā divassā”ti?
an3.70:1.4.eng: “So, Visākhā, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”

an3.70:2.3.eng: The sabbath of the cowherds, the sabbath of the Jains, and the sabbath of the noble ones.

an3.70:2.4.eng: And what is the sabbath of the cowherds?

an3.70:2.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, visākhe, gopālako sāyanhasamaye sāmikānaṃ gāvo niyyātetvā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an3.70:2.5.eng: It’s just like a cowherd who, in the late afternoon, takes the cows back to their owners. They reflect:

an3.70:2.6.pli: ‘ajja kho gāvo amukasmiñca amukasmiñca padese cariṃsu, amukasmiñca amukasmiñca padese pānīyāni piviṃsu;
an3.70:2.6.eng: ‘Today the cows grazed in this spot and that, and they drank in this spot and that.

an3.70:2.7.pli: sve dāni gāvo amukasmiñca amukasmiñca padese carissanti, amukasmiñca amukasmiñca padese pānīyāni pivissantī’ti;
an3.70:2.7.eng: Tomorrow the cows will graze in this spot and that, and drink in this spot and that.’

an3.70:2.8.pli: evamevaṃ kho, visākhe, idhekacco uposathiko iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an3.70:2.8.eng: In the same way, someone keeping the sabbath reflects:

an3.70:2.9.pli: ‘ahaṃ khvajja idañcidañca khādanīyaṃ khādiṃ, idañcidañca bhojanīyaṃ bhuñjiṃ;
an3.70:2.9.eng: ‘Today I ate this and that, and had a meal of this and that.

an3.70:2.10.pli: sve dānāhaṃ idañcidañca khādanīyaṃ khādissāmi, idañcidañca bhojanīyaṃ bhuñjissāmī’ti.
an3.70:2.10.eng: Tomorrow I’ll eat this and that, and have a meal of this and that.’

an3.70:2.11.pli: So tena abhijjhāsahagatena cetasā divasaṃ atināmeti.
an3.70:2.11.eng: And so they spend their day with a mind full of covetousness.

an3.70:2.12.eng: That’s the sabbath of the cowherds.

an3.70:2.13.pli: Evaṃ upavuttho kho, visākhe, gopālakuposatho na mahapphalo hoti na mahānisaṃso na mahājutiko na mahāvipphāro.
an3.70:2.13.eng: When the cowherd’s sabbath is observed like this it’s not very fruitful or beneficial or dazzling or bountiful.

an3.70:3.1.eng: And what is the sabbath of the Jains?

an3.70:3.2.eng: There’s a kind of ascetic belonging to a group called the Jains.

an3.70:3.4.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, ye puratthimāya disāya pāṇā paraṃ yojanasataṃ tesu daṇḍaṃ nikkhipāhi;
an3.70:3.4.eng: ‘Please, good people, don’t hurt any living creatures more than a hundred leagues away to the east.

an3.70:3.5.pli: ye pacchimāya disāya pāṇā paraṃ yojanasataṃ tesu daṇḍaṃ nikkhipāhi;
an3.70:3.5.eng: Don’t hurt any living creatures more than a hundred leagues away to the west.

an3.70:3.6.pli: ye uttarāya disāya pāṇā paraṃ yojanasataṃ tesu daṇḍaṃ nikkhipāhi;
an3.70:3.6.eng: Don’t hurt any living creatures more than a hundred leagues away to the north.

an3.70:3.7.pli: ye dakkhiṇāya disāya pāṇā paraṃ yojanasataṃ tesu daṇḍaṃ nikkhipāhī’ti.
an3.70:3.7.eng: Don’t hurt any living creatures more than a hundred leagues away to the south.’

an3.70:3.8.pli: Iti ekaccānaṃ pāṇānaṃ anuddayāya anukampāya samādapenti, ekaccānaṃ pāṇānaṃ nānuddayāya nānukampāya samādapenti.
an3.70:3.8.eng: So they encourage kindness and sympathy for some creatures and not others.

an3.70:3.9.eng: On the sabbath, they encourage their disciples:

an3.70:3.10.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, sabbacelāni nikkhipitvā evaṃ vadehi—
an3.70:3.10.eng: ‘Please, good people, take off all your clothes and say:

an3.70:3.11.pli: nāhaṃ kvacani kassaci kiñcanatasmiṃ, na ca mama kvacani katthaci kiñcanatatthī’ti.
an3.70:3.11.eng: “I don’t belong to anyone anywhere! And nothing belongs to me anywhere!”’

an3.70:3.12.eng: But their mother and father still know,

an3.70:3.20.eng: Bondservants, workers, and staff still know:

an3.70:3.23.eng: ‘These are my bondservants, workers, and staff.’

an3.70:3.24.pli: Iti yasmiṃ samaye sacce samādapetabbā musāvāde tasmiṃ samaye samādapenti.
an3.70:3.24.eng: So, at a time when they should be encouraged to speak the truth, the Jains encourage them to lie.

an3.70:3.26.pli: So tassā rattiyā accayena bhoge adinnaṃyeva paribhuñjati.
an3.70:3.26.eng: When the night has passed they use their possessions once more, though they’ve not been given back to them.

an3.70:3.28.eng: That’s the sabbath of the Jains.

an3.70:3.29.pli: Evaṃ upavuttho kho, visākhe, nigaṇṭhuposatho na mahapphalo hoti na mahānisaṃso na mahājutiko na mahāvipphāro.
an3.70:3.29.eng: When the Jain’s sabbath is observed like this it’s not very fruitful or beneficial or dazzling or bountiful.

an3.70:4.1.eng: And what is the sabbath of the noble ones?

an3.70:4.2.pli: Upakkiliṭṭhassa, visākhe, cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:4.2.eng: A corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:4.3.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:4.3.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:4.4.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects the Realized One:

an3.70:4.5.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an3.70:4.5.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an3.70:4.6.pli: Tassa tathāgataṃ anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti, seyyathāpi, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa sīsassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:4.6.eng: As they recollect the Realized One, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up. It’s just like cleaning a dirty head by applying effort.

an3.70:5.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa sīsassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:5.1.eng: And how is a dirty head cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:5.2.pli: Kakkañca paṭicca mattikañca paṭicca udakañca paṭicca purisassa ca tajjaṃ vāyāmaṃ paṭicca, evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa sīsassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:5.2.eng: With cleansing paste, clay, and water, and by applying the appropriate effort.

an3.70:5.3.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:5.3.eng: In the same way, a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:6.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:6.1.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:6.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects the Realized One:

an3.70:6.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an3.70:6.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an3.70:6.4.pli: Tassa tathāgataṃ anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti.
an3.70:6.4.eng: As they recollect the Realized One, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.

an3.70:6.6.pli: ‘ariyasāvako brahmuposathaṃ upavasati, brahmunā saddhiṃ saṃvasati, brahmañcassa ārabbha cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti’.
an3.70:6.6.eng: ‘A noble disciple who observes the sabbath of the divinity, living together with the divinity. And because they think of the divinity their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.’

an3.70:6.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti. .1
an3.70:6.7.eng: That’s how a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:7.1.pli: Upakkiliṭṭhassa, visākhe, cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:7.1.eng: A corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:7.2.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:7.2.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:7.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects the teaching:

an3.70:7.4.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
an3.70:7.4.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

an3.70:7.5.pli: Tassa dhammaṃ anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti, seyyathāpi, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa kāyassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:7.5.eng: As they recollect the teaching, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up. It’s just like cleaning a dirty body by applying effort.

an3.70:8.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa kāyassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:8.1.eng: And how is a dirty body cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:8.2.pli: Sottiñca paṭicca, cuṇṇañca paṭicca, udakañca paṭicca, purisassa ca tajjaṃ vāyāmaṃ paṭicca.
an3.70:8.2.eng: With cleanser and powder, water, and by applying the appropriate effort.

an3.70:8.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa kāyassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:8.3.eng: That’s how a dirty body is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:8.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:8.4.eng: In the same way, a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:9.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:9.1.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:9.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects the teaching:

an3.70:9.3.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
an3.70:9.3.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

an3.70:9.4.pli: Tassa dhammaṃ anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti.
an3.70:9.4.eng: As they recollect the teaching, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.

an3.70:9.5.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, visākhe, ‘ariyasāvako dhammuposathaṃ upavasati, dhammena saddhiṃ saṃvasati, dhammañcassa ārabbha cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti’.
an3.70:9.5.eng: This is called: ‘A noble disciple who observes the sabbath of Dhamma, living together with Dhamma. And because they think of the Dhamma their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.’

an3.70:9.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti. .2
an3.70:9.6.eng: That’s how a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:10.1.pli: Upakkiliṭṭhassa, visākhe, cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:10.1.eng: A corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:10.2.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:10.2.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:10.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects the Saṅgha:

an3.70:10.4.pli: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā’ti.
an3.70:10.4.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

an3.70:10.5.pli: Tassa saṅghaṃ anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti, seyyathāpi, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa vatthassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:10.5.eng: As they recollect the Saṅgha, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up. It’s just like cleaning a dirty cloth by applying effort.

an3.70:11.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa vatthassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:11.1.eng: And how is a dirty cloth cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:11.2.pli: Usmañca paṭicca, khārañca paṭicca, gomayañca paṭicca, udakañca paṭicca, purisassa ca tajjaṃ vāyāmaṃ paṭicca.
an3.70:11.2.eng: With salt, lye, cow dung, and water, and by applying the appropriate effort.

an3.70:11.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa vatthassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:11.3.eng: That’s how a dirty cloth is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:11.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:11.4.eng: In the same way, a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:12.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:12.1.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:12.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects the Saṅgha:

an3.70:12.3.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, and worthy of veneration with joined palms. It is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

an3.70:12.4.pli: Tassa saṅghaṃ anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti.
an3.70:12.4.eng: As they recollect the Saṅgha, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.

an3.70:12.5.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, visākhe, ‘ariyasāvako saṅghuposathaṃ upavasati, saṅghena saddhiṃ saṃvasati, saṅghañcassa ārabbha cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti’.
an3.70:12.5.eng: This is called: ‘A noble disciple who observes the sabbath of the Saṅgha, living together with the Saṅgha. And because they think of the Saṅgha their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.’

an3.70:12.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti. .3
an3.70:12.6.eng: That’s how a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:13.1.pli: Upakkiliṭṭhassa, visākhe, cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:13.1.eng: A corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:13.2.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:13.2.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:13.3.pli: Idha, visākhe, ariyasāvako attano sīlāni anussarati akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni.
an3.70:13.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects their own ethical conduct, which is intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

an3.70:13.4.pli: Tassa sīlaṃ anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti, seyyathāpi, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa ādāsassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:13.4.eng: As they recollect their ethical conduct, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up. It’s just like cleaning a dirty mirror by applying effort.

an3.70:14.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa ādāsassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:14.1.eng: And how is a dirty mirror cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:14.2.pli: Telañca paṭicca, chārikañca paṭicca, vālaṇḍupakañca paṭicca, purisassa ca tajjaṃ vāyāmaṃ paṭicca.
an3.70:14.2.eng: With oil, ash, a rolled-up cloth, and by applying the appropriate effort.

an3.70:14.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa ādāsassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:14.3.eng: That’s how a dirty mirror is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:14.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:14.4.eng: In the same way, a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:15.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:15.1.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:15.2.pli: Idha, visākhe, ariyasāvako attano sīlāni anussarati akhaṇḍāni …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikāni.
an3.70:15.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects their own ethical conduct, which is intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

an3.70:15.3.pli: Tassa sīlaṃ anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti.
an3.70:15.3.eng: As they recollect their ethical conduct, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.

an3.70:15.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, visākhe, ‘ariyasāvako sīluposathaṃ upavasati, sīlena saddhiṃ saṃvasati, sīlañcassa ārabbha cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti’.
an3.70:15.4.eng: This is called: ‘A noble disciple who observes the sabbath of ethical conduct, living together with ethics. And because they think of their ethical conduct their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.’

an3.70:15.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti. .4
an3.70:15.5.eng: That’s how a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:16.1.pli: Upakkiliṭṭhassa, visākhe, cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:16.1.eng: A corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:16.2.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:16.2.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:16.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects the deities:

an3.70:16.4.pli: ‘santi devā cātumahārājikā, santi devā tāvatiṃsā, santi devā yāmā, santi devā tusitā, santi devā nimmānaratino, santi devā paranimmitavasavattino, santi devā brahmakāyikā, santi devā tatuttari.
an3.70:16.4.eng: ‘There are the gods of the four great kings, the gods of the thirty-three, the gods of Yama, the joyful gods, the gods who love to create, the gods who control what is created by others, the gods of the Divinity’s host, and gods even higher than these.

an3.70:16.5.pli: Yathārūpāya saddhāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthupapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā saddhā saṃvijjati.
an3.70:16.5.eng: When those deities passed away from here, they were reborn there because of their faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. I, too, have the same kind of faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.’

an3.70:16.6.pli: Yathārūpena sīlena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthupapannā, mayhampi tathārūpaṃ sīlaṃ saṃvijjati.

an3.70:16.7.pli: Yathārūpena sutena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthupapannā, mayhampi tathārūpaṃ sutaṃ saṃvijjati.

an3.70:16.8.pli: Yathārūpena cāgena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthupapannā, mayhampi tathārūpo cāgo saṃvijjati.

an3.70:16.9.pli: Yathārūpāya paññāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthupapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā paññā saṃvijjatī’ti.

an3.70:16.10.pli: Tassa attano ca tāsañca devatānaṃ saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti, seyyathāpi, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa jātarūpassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:16.10.eng: As they recollect the faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom of both themselves and those deities, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up. It’s just like cleansing corrupt native gold by applying effort.

an3.70:17.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa jātarūpassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:17.1.eng: And how is corrupt native gold cleansed by applying effort?

an3.70:17.2.pli: Ukkañca paṭicca, loṇañca paṭicca, gerukañca paṭicca, nāḷikasaṇḍāsañca paṭicca, purisassa ca tajjaṃ vāyāmaṃ paṭicca.
an3.70:17.2.eng: With a furnace, flux, a blowpipe, and tongs, and by applying the appropriate effort.

an3.70:17.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa jātarūpassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:17.3.eng: That’s how corrupt native gold is cleansed by applying effort.

an3.70:17.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti.
an3.70:17.4.eng: In the same way, a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:18.1.pli: Kathañca, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti?
an3.70:18.1.eng: And how is a corrupt mind cleaned by applying effort?

an3.70:18.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple recollects the deities:

an3.70:18.3.pli: ‘santi devā cātumahārājikā, santi devā tāvatiṃsā …pe… santi devā tatuttari.
an3.70:18.3.eng: ‘There are the gods of the four great kings, the gods of the thirty-three, the gods of Yama, the joyful gods, the gods who love to imagine, the gods who control what is imagined by others, the gods of the Divinity’s host, and gods even higher than these.

an3.70:18.4.pli: Yathārūpāya saddhāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthupapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā saddhā saṃvijjati.
an3.70:18.4.eng: When those deities passed away from here, they were reborn there because of their faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. I, too, have the same kind of faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.’

an3.70:18.8.pli: paññāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthupapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā paññā saṃvijjatī’ti.

an3.70:18.9.pli: Tassa attano ca tāsañca devatānaṃ saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussarato cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti.
an3.70:18.9.eng: As they recollect the faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom of both themselves and those deities, their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.

an3.70:18.10.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, visākhe, ‘ariyasāvako devatuposathaṃ upavasati, devatāhi saddhiṃ saṃvasati, devatā ārabbha cittaṃ pasīdati, pāmojjaṃ uppajjati, ye cittassa upakkilesā te pahīyanti’.
an3.70:18.10.eng: This is called: ‘A noble disciple who observes the sabbath of the deities, living together with the deities. And because they think of the deities their mind becomes clear, joy arises, and mental corruptions are given up.’

an3.70:18.11.pli: Evaṃ kho, visākhe, upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa upakkamena pariyodapanā hoti. .5
an3.70:18.11.eng: That’s how a corrupt mind is cleaned by applying effort.

an3.70:19.1.pli: Sa kho so, visākhe, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

an3.70:19.2.pli: ‘yāvajīvaṃ arahanto pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā nihitadaṇḍā nihitasatthā lajjī dayāpannā sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharanti;
an3.70:19.2.eng: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They are scrupulous and kind, and live full of sympathy for all living beings.

an3.70:19.3.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharāmi.
an3.70:19.3.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. I’ll be scrupulous and kind, and live full of sympathy for all living beings.

an3.70:19.4.pli: Imināpi aṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissati.
an3.70:19.4.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.

an3.70:20.1.pli: Yāvajīvaṃ arahanto adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭiviratā dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharanti;
an3.70:20.1.eng: As long as they live, the perfected ones give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.

an3.70:20.2.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharāmi.
an3.70:20.2.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up stealing. I’ll take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. I’ll keep myself clean by not thieving.

an3.70:20.3.pli: Imināpi aṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissati.
an3.70:20.3.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.

an3.70:21.1.pli: Yāvajīvaṃ arahanto abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī ārācārī viratā methunā gāmadhammā;
an3.70:21.1.eng: As long as they live, the perfected ones give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.

an3.70:21.2.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
an3.70:21.2.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up unchastity. I will be chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.

an3.70:21.3.pli: Imināpi aṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissati.
an3.70:21.3.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.

an3.70:22.1.pli: Yāvajīvaṃ arahanto musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭiviratā saccavādī saccasandhā thetā paccayikā avisaṃvādakā lokassa;
an3.70:22.1.eng: As long as they live, the perfected ones give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.

an3.70:22.2.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassa.
an3.70:22.2.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up lying. I’ll speak the truth and stick to the truth. I’ll be honest and dependable, and won’t trick the world with my words.

an3.70:22.3.pli: Imināpi aṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissati.
an3.70:22.3.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.

an3.70:23.1.pli: Yāvajīvaṃ arahanto surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānaṃ pahāya surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā;
an3.70:23.1.eng: As long as they live, the perfected ones give up beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an3.70:23.2.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānaṃ pahāya surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato.
an3.70:23.2.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an3.70:23.3.pli: Imināpi aṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissati.
an3.70:23.3.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.

an3.70:24.1.pli: Yāvajīvaṃ arahanto ekabhattikā rattūparatā viratā vikālabhojanā;
an3.70:24.1.eng: As long as they live, the perfected ones eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and from food at the wrong time.

an3.70:24.2.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ ekabhattiko rattūparato virato vikālabhojanā.
an3.70:24.2.eng: I, too, for this day and night will eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.

an3.70:24.3.pli: Imināpi aṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissati.
an3.70:24.3.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.

an3.70:25.1.eng: As long as they live, the perfected ones refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music; and attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.

an3.70:25.2.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ naccagītavāditavisūkadassanamālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭivirato.
an3.70:25.2.eng: I, too, for this day and night will refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music ; and attiring and adorning myself with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.

an3.70:25.3.pli: Imināpi aṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissati.
an3.70:25.3.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.

an3.70:26.1.pli: Yāvajīvaṃ arahanto uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ pahāya uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭiviratā nīcaseyyaṃ kappenti mañcake vā tiṇasanthārake vā;
an3.70:26.1.eng: As long as they live, the perfected ones give up high and luxurious beds. They sleep in a low place, either a cot or a straw mat.

an3.70:26.2.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ pahāya uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato nīcaseyyaṃ kappemi mañcake vā tiṇasanthārake vā.
an3.70:26.2.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up high and luxurious beds. I’ll sleep in a low place, either a cot or a straw mat.

an3.70:26.3.pli: Imināpi aṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissatī’ti.
an3.70:26.3.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’

an3.70:27.1.eng: That’s the sabbath of the noble ones.

an3.70:27.2.pli: Evaṃ upavuttho kho, visākhe, ariyuposatho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro.
an3.70:27.2.eng: When the sabbath of the noble ones is observed like this it’s very fruitful and beneficial and dazzling and bountiful.

an3.70:28.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, visākhe, yo imesaṃ soḷasannaṃ mahājanapadānaṃ pahūtarattaratanānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreyya, seyyathidaṃ—
an3.70:28.2.eng: Suppose you were to rule as sovereign lord over these sixteen great countries—Aṅga, Magadha, Kāsi, Kosala, Vajji, Malla, Cetī, Vaccha, Kuru, Pañcāla, Maccha, Sūrasena, Assaka, Avanti, Gandhāra, and Kamboja—full of the seven treasures.

an3.70:28.3.pli: aṅgānaṃ, magadhānaṃ, kāsīnaṃ, kosalānaṃ, vajjīnaṃ, mallānaṃ, cetīnaṃ, vaṅgānaṃ, kurūnaṃ, pañcālānaṃ, macchānaṃ, sūrasenānaṃ, assakānaṃ, avantīnaṃ, gandhārānaṃ, kambojānaṃ, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatassa uposathassa etaṃ kalaṃ nāgghati soḷasiṃ.
an3.70:28.3.eng: This wouldn’t be worth a sixteenth part of the sabbath with its eight factors.

an3.70:28.5.pli: Kapaṇaṃ, visākhe, mānusakaṃ rajjaṃ dibbaṃ sukhaṃ upanidhāya.
an3.70:28.5.eng: Because human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.

an3.70:29.1.pli: Yāni, visākhe, mānusakāni paññāsa vassāni, cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
an3.70:29.1.eng: Fifty years in the human realm is one day and night for the gods of the four great kings.

an3.70:29.2.eng: Thirty such days make up a month.

an3.70:29.3.eng: Twelve such months make up a year.

an3.70:29.4.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbāni pañca vassasatāni cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an3.70:29.4.eng: The lifespan of the gods of the four great kings is five hundred of these heavenly years.

an3.70:29.5.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
an3.70:29.5.eng: It’s possible that some woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the gods of the four great kings.

an3.70:29.6.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
an3.70:29.6.eng: This is what I was referring to when I said:

an3.70:29.7.eng: ‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’

an3.70:30.1.pli: Yaṃ, visākhe, mānusakaṃ vassasataṃ, tāvatiṃsānaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
an3.70:30.1.eng: A hundred years in the human realm is one day and night for the gods of the thirty-three.

an3.70:30.2.eng: Thirty such days make up a month.

an3.70:30.3.eng: Twelve such months make up a year.

an3.70:30.4.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbaṃ vassasahassaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an3.70:30.4.eng: The lifespan of the gods of the thirty-three is a thousand of these heavenly years.

an3.70:30.5.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tāvatiṃsānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
an3.70:30.5.eng: It’s possible that some woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the gods of the thirty-three.

an3.70:30.6.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
an3.70:30.6.eng: This is what I was referring to when I said:

an3.70:30.7.eng: ‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’

an3.70:31.1.pli: Yāni, visākhe, mānusakāni dve vassasatāni, yāmānaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
an3.70:31.1.eng: Two hundred years in the human realm is one day and night for the gods of Yama.

an3.70:31.2.eng: Thirty such days make up a month.

an3.70:31.3.eng: Twelve such months make up a year.

an3.70:31.4.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbāni dve vassasahassāni yāmānaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an3.70:31.4.eng: The lifespan of the gods of Yama is two thousand of these heavenly years.

an3.70:31.5.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā yāmānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
an3.70:31.5.eng: It’s possible that some woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the gods of Yama.

an3.70:31.6.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
an3.70:31.6.eng: This is what I was referring to when I said:

an3.70:31.7.eng: ‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’

an3.70:32.1.pli: Yāni, visākhe, mānusakāni cattāri vassasatāni, tusitānaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
an3.70:32.1.eng: Four hundred years in the human realm is one day and night for the joyful gods.

an3.70:32.2.eng: Thirty such days make up a month.

an3.70:32.3.eng: Twelve such months make up a year.

an3.70:32.4.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbāni cattāri vassasahassāni tusitānaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an3.70:32.4.eng: The lifespan of the joyful gods is four thousand of these heavenly years.

an3.70:32.5.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tusitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
an3.70:32.5.eng: It’s possible that some woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the joyful gods.

an3.70:32.6.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
an3.70:32.6.eng: This is what I was referring to when I said:

an3.70:32.7.eng: ‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’

an3.70:33.1.pli: Yāni, visākhe, mānusakāni aṭṭha vassasatāni, nimmānaratīnaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
an3.70:33.1.eng: Eight hundred years in the human realm is one day and night for the gods who love to create.

an3.70:33.2.eng: Thirty such days make up a month.

an3.70:33.3.eng: Twelve such months make up a year.

an3.70:33.4.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbāni aṭṭha vassasahassāni nimmānaratīnaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an3.70:33.4.eng: The life span of the gods who love to create is eight thousand of these heavenly years.

an3.70:33.5.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā nimmānaratīnaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
an3.70:33.5.eng: It’s possible that some woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the gods who love to create.

an3.70:33.6.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
an3.70:33.6.eng: This is what I was referring to when I said:

an3.70:33.7.eng: ‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’

an3.70:34.1.pli: Yāni, visākhe, mānusakāni soḷasa vassasatāni, paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
an3.70:34.1.eng: Sixteen hundred years in the human realm is one day and night for the gods who control what is created by others.

an3.70:34.2.eng: Thirty such days make up a month.

an3.70:34.3.eng: Twelve such months make up a year.

an3.70:34.4.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbāni soḷasa vassasahassāni paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an3.70:34.4.eng: The life span of the gods who control what is created by others is sixteen thousand of these heavenly years.

an3.70:34.5.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
an3.70:34.5.eng: It’s possible that some woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the gods who control what is created by others.

an3.70:34.6.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, visākhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
an3.70:34.6.eng: This is what I was referring to when I said:

an3.70:34.7.eng: ‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’

an3.70:35.1.eng: You shouldn’t kill living creatures, or steal,

an3.70:35.2.pli: Musā na bhāse na ca majjapo siyā;

an3.70:35.4.eng: and don’t eat at night, the wrong time.

an3.70:36.1.pli: Mālaṃ na dhāre na ca gandhamācare,
an3.70:36.1.eng: Not wearing garlands or applying fragrance,

an3.70:36.2.eng: you should sleep on a low bed, <j>or a mat on the ground.

an3.70:36.3.eng: This is the eight-factored sabbath, they say,

an3.70:36.4.eng: explained by the Buddha, <j>who has gone to suffering’s end.

an3.70:37.1.pli: Cando ca suriyo ca ubho sudassanā,
an3.70:37.1.eng: The moon and sun are both fair to see,

an3.70:37.2.eng: radiating as far as they revolve.

an3.70:37.3.eng: Those dispellers of darkness, travellers in midair,

an3.70:37.4.eng: shine in the firmament, lighting up the quarters.

an3.70:38.1.eng: All of the wealth that’s found in this realm—

an3.70:39.1.eng: they’re not worth a sixteenth part

an3.70:39.2.eng: of the sabbath with its eight factors,

an3.70:39.3.eng: as starlight cannot rival the moon.

an3.70:40.1.pli: Tasmā hi nārī ca naro ca sīlavā,
an3.70:40.1.eng: So an ethical woman or man,

an3.70:40.2.eng: who has observed the eight-factored sabbath,

an3.70:40.3.eng: having made merit whose outcome is happiness,

an3.70:40.4.eng: blameless, they go to a heavenly place.”
